subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: The sentence in (1a) describes an event that occurred in the past of John repairing the car. In (1b), this sentence is embedded under a causative verb, make. The new sentence expresses the fact that the event of John repairing the car was brought about or caused by Mary.

row.entry: Mary made John repair the car.

subsection.p: Sentences such as those in (1b) are called causative sentences. The term causative derives from the semantics of these constructions. It is meant to express the fact that the event reported in (1a) is caused by someone. Mary in (1b) is called the causer, the person that brought about the event described by its verbal complement (repair the car), and John is called the causee. Other constructions that are like (1b) are given in (2):

(2)
a. Mary let John repair the car.
b. Mary had John repair the car.

We call causatives of the types found in English analytical causatives, since the causative verb make (or let, have) and the verb in the complement are two independent words. Analytical causatives are also found in Romance languages, as the Catalan, French, Italian, Portuguese, and Spanish examples in (3) show:

(3)
a. Marie fit reparer la voiture à Jean. (French)
b. Maria fece riparare la macchina a Gianni. (Italian)
c. Maria hizo arreglar el coche a Juan. (Spanish)
d. A Maria fez arranjar a máquina à João. (European Portuguese)
e. La Maria va fer arreglar el cotxe al Joan. (Catalan)
Mary made repair the car to John
‘Mary made John repair the car.’

Although morphologically English and Romance causatives are similar (in both cases we have two verbs), syntactically the causative and the infinitive verbs (e.g., fit reparer in (3a)) in French and more generally in Romance languages behave as a single complex verb. This behavior is apparent in the distribution of the infinitive arguments and in the properties of these arguments with respect to certain syntactic processes, as we will see in the following sections. Here we will mainly concentrate on Romance causatives.

Since Kayne's (1975) seminal work on French causatives, many studies have looked at the causatives in various Romance languages (see Rouveret and Vergnaud 1980; Manzini 1983b; Burzio 1986; Zubizarreta 1986; Bordelois 1988; Gonçalves 1999; Treviño 1990; Guasti 1993). For expository purposes, this review of analytical causatives will take Italian as a representative language of the Romance family and will explicitly point out the divergences among Romance languages.

subsection.heading: 2 The syntax of Romance causatives
subsection.p: Various properties single out Romance causatives. The most prominent ones are the distribution of the thematic subject of the infinitive verb embedded under the causative, and the behavior of its arguments with respect to certain syntactic processes like cliticization and passivization.

subsection.heading: 2.1 Distributional properties of the infinitive's subject
subsection.p: We have seen that in English the infinitive's subject surfaces between the causative verb and the infinitive, as in (1b). In Romance languages, the same order is generally prohibited, as seen in (4):

(4)
a. *Maria ha fatto Gianni riparare la macchina.
Maria has made Gianni repair the car
‘Maria made Gianni repair the car.’
b. *Paolo ha fatto la classe ridere.
Paolo has made the class laugh
‘Paolo made the class laugh.’

The subject must occur in a position at the very end of the sentence, as in (3) above. In causatives based on transitive verbs, the subject of the infinitive, Gianni, appears after the direct object la macchina (the car) and is preceded by the preposition a (to), as in (3b) and (5a). Alternatively, it is introduced by the preposition da (by), as in (5b). These are not just two ways of expressing the causee. In fact, (5a) and (5b) are two different constructions that have some properties in common, but differ with respect to a number of other properties, as we will extensively discuss in section 2.3. Since Kayne's 1975 work, these two constructions have been named faire-infinitif (FI), (5a), and faire-par (FP), (5b):

(5)
a. Maria ha fatto riparare la macchina a Gianni. (faire-infinitif)
Maria has made repair the car to Gianni
‘Maria made Gianni repair the car.’
b. Maria ha fatto riparare la macchina da Gianni. (faire-par)
Maria has made repair the car by Gianni
‘Maria had the car repaired by Gianni.’

In causatives of intransitive unergative verbs, as in (6), the subject of the infinitive surfaces after the infinitive verb, but is not and cannot be preceded by any preposition. This causative construction is also considered an instance of the faire-infinitif construction.

(6)
Paolo ha fatto ridere la classe. (faire-infinitif)
Paolo has made laugh the class
‘Paolo made the class laugh.’
‘Paolo made the class laugh.’

The English order SV(O) displayed in (1b) is unacceptable in Romance causatives. Exceptions are some dialects of Spanish, according to Moore (1991) and European Portuguese (EP). For example, in EP, beyond the order in (3) found in the other Romance languages, one finds a causative construction displaying the English order, as shown in (7):

(7)
Os pais mandaram os meniños comprar(em) os livros.
the parents made the children buy(-3PL) the books
‘The parents made the children buy the books.’

Interestingly, in this EP construction, the infinitive verb can be inflected, that is, it can display overt subject agreement. In contrast, in the other causative construction, in (3d), typically found in the other Romance languages, inflected infinitives are prohibited. Notice also that the order SV(O) is perfectly acceptable in all Romance languages when the causative verb is replaced by a verb of perception as illustrated in (8). Compare (8) with the minimal pairs in (4):

(8)
a. Maria ha visto Gianni riparare la macchina.
Maria has seen Gianni repair the car
‘Maria saw Gianni repair the car.’
b. Paolo ha visto tutta la classe ridere.
Paolo has seen whole the class laugh
‘Paolo saw the whole class laugh.’

The contrast between the ungrammatical sentences in (4) and the grammatical ones in (8) suggests that the Romance causative construction has properties that single it out from other infinitival constructions. With the exception of the EP construction in (7), all the sentences examined show that adjacency between the causative and the infinitive verbs cannot be interrupted by the subject of the infinitive. This fact may suggest that the causative and the infinitive verbs count as a single unit, an interpretation that is supported by other pieces of data.

subsection.heading: 2.2 Syntactic processes in causative constructions
subsection.p: In this section, we are going to examine the syntactic behavior of arguments of the infinitive verb with respect to two processes, cliticization and NP-movement, as it occurs in passive constructions. With respect to these two processes the two causative constructions, faire-infinitif and faire-par are essentially alike. Therefore, only examples of faire-infinitif will be offered.

subsection.heading: 2.2.1.1 Clitic placement
subsection.p: Consider the sentence in (5a), repeated below for convenience:

(5)
a. Maria ha fatto riparare la macchina a Gianni.
Maria has made repair the car to Gianni
‘Maria made Gianni repair the car.’

The direct object of riparare can be expressed as an accusative clitic that appears in a position preceding the causative verb, as in (9a). Placement of this clitic after the infinitive is generally unacceptable, although some speakers (see Burzio 1986) accept it marginally (see (9b)):

(9)
a. Maria la fa riparare a Gianni.
Maria it-FEM-SG-ACC makes repair to Gianni
‘Maria made Gianni repair it.’
b. ??/*Maria fa ripararla a Gianni.
Maria makes repair+it-FEM-SG-ACC to Gianni
‘Maria made Gianni repair it.’

Now compare the placement of the clitic in (9) with the placement of the clitic in other non-causative constructions, e.g., the control structures in (10). The direct object in (10a), il libro (the book), can be cliticized and placed after the infinitive verb, as in (10b). Placement of it in a position preceding the main verb, promettere (promise), yields a severe ungrammatical result, as illustrated in (10c):

(10)
a. Gianni promise di leggere il libro.
Gianni promised to read the book
b. Gianni promise di leggerlo
Gianni promised to read+it-MASC-SG-ACC
‘Gianni promised to read it.’
c. *Gianni lo promise di leggere.
Gianni it-MASC-SG-ACC promised to read
‘Gianni promised to read it.’

Facts similar to those just discussed can be observed with ne-cliticization, that is, when we cliticize the head of an internal argument. Consider the causative sentence in (11a). The head of the NP, libri (books) in (11a), can be expressed by the clitic ne (of + them). In causatives, this clitic must surface on the causative verb, not on the infinitive verb, that is, (11b) is the only grammatical possibility of placing the clitic ne.

(11)
a. La maestra fa leggere molti libri a Paolo.
the teacher makes read many books to Paolo
‘The teacher makes Paolo read many books.’
b. La maestra ne fa leggere molti a Paolo.
the teacher of+them makes read many to Paolo
‘The teacher makes Paolo read many of them.’

On the contrary, in non causative constructions, e.g., a control structure in (12a), the clitic ne standing in for the head of the internal argument of the infinitive surfaces after the infinitive, as in (12b). Placement of this clitic before the main verb promise leads to an ungrammatical result, (12c):

(12)
a. Gianni promise di leggere molti libri.
Gianni promised to read many books
b. Gianni promise di leggerne molti
Gianni promised to read+of+them many
c. *Gianni ne promise di leggere.
Gianni of+them promised to read
‘Gianni promised to read many of them.’

The set of data in (10) and (12) displays the normal distribution of clitics in infinitival constructions. What is exceptional is the placement of clitics in causative constructions. Not only is the placement of clitics on the causative verb possible, but it is the standard solution, appearance of the clitic on the infinitive leading to ungrammatical or rather marginally acceptable results.

In causatives, clitics standing in for the internal argument of the infinitive must cliticize on the main verb. The process by which this occurs is referred to as clitic climbing in the literature (see Kayne 1989b, 1991).

The subject of the infinitive introduced by the preposition a (to) can also be expressed by a dative clitic placed before the causative verb, as in (13b). No clitic exists for the subject of the infinitive when it is introduced by the preposition da (by).

(13)
Maria gli fa riparare la macchina.
Maria to+him makes repair the car
‘Maria makes him repair the car.’
Appearance of the dative clitic after the infinitive is unanimously considered unacceptable, as (14) illustrates:

(14)
*Maria fa riparargli la macchina.
Maria makes repair+to+him the car
‘Maria makes him repair the car.’

Generally, a clitic is placed close to the verb that determines its thematic role, its case, and its grammatical function. This is illustrated in (10) and (12). For example, in (10) the argument of the verb leggere (read) can be expressed by a clitic following the infinitive verb, which is the verb that determines its thematic role, its case, and its grammatical function. In causatives, instead, clitics expressing arguments of the infinitive surface on the causative verb. In a way, these arguments seem to act as arguments of the causative verbs as well, a fact that is in need of explanation.

subsection.heading: 2.2.1.2 Passivization and NP movement
subsection.p: When the causative verb is in the passive, the internal argument of the infinitive behaves as a direct object of the causative verb as well: it undergoes NP-movement to the subject position of the causative verb:

(15)
a. La macchina è stata fatta riparare a Gianni da Maria.
the car is been made-FEM-SG repair to Gianni by Maria
‘The car was made to be repaired to Gianni by Maria.’
b. La macchina è stata fatta riparare da Gianni (*da Maria).
the car is been made-FEM-SG repair by Gianni (*by Maria).
‘The car was made to be repaired by Gianni by Maria.’

In passive sentences, the passive morpheme on the verb absorbs structural accusative case. As a consequence, the D-structure object is forced to move to a position where it receives nominative case. Since in (15) it is the D-structure object of the infinitive that undergoes movement, we must conclude first that the infinitive by itself has no case to assign; second that movement to the structural subject position of the causative verb ensures that the internal argument of the infinitive, la macchina (the car), gets a case, precisely nominative case. Since case is not assigned by the infinitive, one can conjecture that it is assigned by the causative and the infinitive taken as a complex verb. When the causative verb is passivized, the complex verb as a whole looses its ability to assign accusative case and forces movement of the D-structure object to the subject position. As in all passive sentences the subject, or in this case, the causer, Maria in (5), can be optionally expressed with the by phrase. Passivization is possible with the causative construction FP as well as seen in (15b), obtained by (5b). In this case, however, the presence of a by phrase standing in for the causer yields a very marginal result.

Passivization of the causative verb and NP-movement are perfectly natural in Italian and in EP, as seen in (16a) (see Gonçalves 1999). In other Romance languages, there is variation and restrictions apply. Variation exists among the speakers of Spanish concerning the status of passivization in causatives (see Moore 1991). Zubizarretta (1986) reports that the equivalent of (15) is ungrammatical in Spanish. Guasti (1993) and Treviño (1990) give examples perfectly acceptable for Spanish speakers (see (16b)).

(16)
a. O carro foi mandado arranjar à João.
the car was made repair to João
‘The car was made to be repaired by João.’
b. La catedral fue hecha costruir por el Papa.
the cathedral was made-FEM-SG build by the Pope
‘The cathedral was made to be built by the Pope.’
Passivization in French is generally reported to yield ungrammatical results, as shown in (17) (see Kayne 1975; Zubizarreta 1986):

(17)
*La voiture a été fait reparer par Jean.
the car has been made repair by Jean
‘The car was made to be repaired by Jean.’

In summary, we have seen that the arguments of an infinitive after a causative verb display a peculiar behavior: while being arguments of the infinitive, they behave as if they were arguments of the causative verb, as well. The direct object of the infinitive can be expressed by an accusative clitic surfacing before the causative verb and undergoes NP-movement when this verb is in the passive. The subject of the infinitive can be expressed by a dative clitic.

subsection.heading: 2.2.2 Causatives based on intransitive unergative verbs
2.2.2.1 Cliticization
subsection.p: In causatives based on intransitive unergative verbs, the subject of the infinitive must appear at the end of the sentence, as we saw in (6). It can be expressed by an accusative clitic, as direct objects can (see (18a)):

(18)
Paolo l’ ha fatta ridere.
Paolo her has made-FEM laugh
‘Paolo made her laugh.’
Appearance of the clitic on the infinitive leads to severe ungrammaticality, as in (19):

(19)
*Paolo fa riderla.
Paolo makes laugh+her
‘Paolo makes her laugh.’
Since an unergative verb does not assign accusative case, this case must be supplied by the causative verb.

Let us now consider the process of ne-cliticization. Take the sentence in (20a). The head of the NP subject molti bambini (many children) can be cliticized by the clitic ne (of + them) and this must appear on the causative verb, as in (20b):

(20)
a. Ciò ha fatto piangere molti bambini.
this has made cry many children
‘This has made many children cry.’
b. Ciò ne ha fatti piangere molti.
this of+them has made-MASC-PL cry many
‘This has made many of them cry.’

subsection.heading: 2.2.2.2 Passivization and NP movement
subsection.p: The subject of the intransitive verb embedded under a causative verb may undergo NP-movement, like a direct object, and becomes the subject of the causative sentence when fare is passivized. An optional by phrase, dal dottore (by the doctor), can express the underlying subject of the causative verb:

(21)
Molti bambini sono stati fatti piangere per nulla dal dottore.
many children are been made-MASC-PL cry for nothing by+the doctor
‘Many children have been made to cry for nothing by the doctor.’

Molti bambini (many children) is the subject of piangere (cry) and thus receives a thematic role from it. As we saw earlier in section 2.2.1, the arguments of the infinitives behave somehow as arguments of the causative verbs. Here we have seen that the subject of the infinitive behaves as an object: it can be expressed by an accusative clitic and undergoes NP-movement to the subject position of the causative verb when this is passivized.

subsection.heading: 2.2.3 Causatives based on unaccusative verbs
subsection.p: In declarative sentences the internal argument of an unaccusative verb can surface both before or after the verb (at least in Catalan, Italian, and Spanish), as shown in (22):

(22)
a. Molti studenti arrivarono in ritardo.
‘Many students arrived late.’
b. Arrivarono in ritardo molti studenti.
arrived late many students
‘Many students arrived late.’
In causatives based on unaccusative verbs, the internal argument of the infinitive must stay in the postverbal position, as illustrated in (23):

(23)
Lo sciopero ha fatto arrivare molti studenti in ritardo.
the strike has made arrive many students late
‘The strike made many students arrive late.’

subsection.heading: 2.2.3.1 Cliticization, passivization, and NP movement
subsection.p: The NP-internal argument of the infinitive can be expressed by an accusative clitic surfacing on the causative verb, as in (24a), and its head can be expressed by the clitic ne, as in (24b):

(24)
a. Lo sciopero li ha fatti arrivare in ritardo.
the strike them has made-MASC-PL arrive late
‘The strike made them arrive late.’
b. Lo sciopero ne ha fatti arrivare molti in ritardo.
the strike of+them has made-MASC-PL arrive many late
‘The strike made many of them arrive late.’

Finally, it may undergo NP-movement to the subject position of the causative verb when this is passivized. In this case, as in all passive sentences, an optional by phrase expressing the causer can be used (see 25b):

(25)
a. Molti studenti sono stati fatti arrivare in ritardo.
many students were been made arrive late
‘Many students have been made to arrive late.’
b. Molti bambini sono stati fatti nascere da giovani ostetriche.
many children were been made born by young midwives
‘Many babies were made to be born by young midwives.’

Since unaccusative verbs do not assign accusative case, this case in (24a) must come from elsewhere. We must then conclude that the causative verb is playing a role in the process of case assignment. Again, these data show that the internal argument of the infinitive acts as an argument of the causative verb, as well. Notice that causatives based on unaccusatives behave as causatives based on unergatives as far as cliticization and NP-movement are concerned.

subsection.heading: 2.2.4 Summary
subsection.p: In Romance causatives based on transitive verbs, the direct object of the infinitive behaves as a direct object of the causative verb, and the subject of the infinitive as an indirect object. In causatives based on intransitive unergative verbs, the subject of the infinitive behaves as a direct object of the causative verb and, finally, in causatives based on unaccusative verbs, the internal argument of the infinitive acts as a direct object of the causative verb. One way to interpret these facts is by assuming that although Romance causative sentences include two morphologically distinct verbs, for syntactic purposes these two verbs behave as a single complex verb, an idea that we will develop in section 2.4. So far, we have examined some properties that are common to the faire-infinitif and to the faire-par construction. It is now time to see how these two constructions differ.

subsection.heading: 2.3 The faire-infinitif and the faire-par constructions
subsection.p: Since Kayne's 1975 work on French causatives, two types of constructions are distinguished in Romance languages: faire-infinitif (FI) illustrated in (5a) earlier and repeated in (26a) and faire-par (FP) illustrated in (5b) and repeated in (26b). In both constructions, the infinitive subject appears at the end of the sentence. However, while in the former case the causee is introduced by the preposition à (to), in the latter it is introduced by the preposition par (by) (Italian a and da respectively in (26a, b)). Causative sentences lacking the causee as in (26c) are also instances of the FP construction, as we will prove in 2.3.3.

(26)
a. Maria ha fatto riparare la machina a Gianni.
Maria has made repair the car to Gianni
‘Maria made Gianni repair the car.’
b. Maria ha fatto riparare la macchina da Gianni.
Maria has made repair the car by Gianni
‘Maria had the car repaired by Gianni.’
c. Maria ha fatto riparare la macchina.
Maria has made repair the car
‘Maria had the car repaired.’

subsection.heading: 2.3.1 Status of the causee in the two causative constructions
subsection.p: A major difference between the two causative structures is that the causee in the FI construction is an argument, whereas it is an adjunct in the FP construction, as shown by Burzio (1986). Binding of an anaphor is a standard test for argumenthood. In (27a) and (27b), instances of the FI construction, the causee binds the anaphor proprio (‘own’) and se stesso (‘himself’), while it does not in the FP construction in (27c) and (27d), since it is an adjunct.

(27)
a. Faremo curare i proprii
interessi ai nostri clientii.
(we) will make take care of the own interests to our customers
‘We will make our customers take care of their own interests.’
b. La polizia fece accusare se stessoi
a Giannii.
the police made accuse himself to Gianni
‘The police made Gianni accuse himself.’
c. *Faremo curare i proprii
interessi dai nostri clientii.
(we) will make take care of the own interests to our customers
‘We will make their own interests taken care of by our customers.’
d. *La polizia fece accusare se stessoi
da Giannii.
the police made accuse himself by Gianni
‘The police had himself accused by Gianni.’

In causatives based on intransitive verbs, the causee is an argument and not an adjunct. It cannot be omitted, as in (28a) and it can bind an anaphor, as in (28b). Thus, causatives based on intransitive verbs are also instances of the FI construction.

(28)
a. *Paolo ha fatto dormire.
Paolo has made sleep
‘Paolo had (someone) sleep.’
b. Faremo parlare ogni autorei
del suoi
libro.
(we) will make speak every author of his (own) book
‘We will make every author talk about his book.’
In summary, causatives may take two forms referred to as faire-infinitif and faire-par. In the former, the causee is an argument, while in the latter it is an (optional) adjunct.

subsection.heading: 2.3.2 Similarities between the passive and the FP construction
subsection.p: Kayne (1975) and Burzio (1986) pointed out that the FP construction resembles the passive construction. The most evident similarity is that the causee is expressed in the same way the D-structure subject is expressed in passive sentences, that is, by a PP headed by the preposition da (by), a by phrase. (29) is an example of passive sentence with the by phrase:

(29)
L’ Italia fu battuta dal Belgio.
the Italy was beaten by the Belgium
‘The Italian team was beaten by the Belgian team.’

Other less evident properties include the following. Idiomatic expressions, like fare il furbo (‘be the smart one’) that cannot be passivized cannot appear in the FP construction. This is illustrated in (30):

(30)
a. *Il furbo è fatto da Gianni.
the smart one is done by Gianni
‘The smart one is made by Gianni.’
b. *Ciò ha fatto fare il furbo da Gianni.
this has made make the smart one by Gianni
‘This had (it) tried to be smart by Gianni.’

Expressions of inalienable possession cannot be used in passive sentences, neither can they appear in the FP construction. The sentences in (31) are ungrammatical under an inalienable possession reading of la mano (‘the hand’).

(31)
a. *La mano è stata alzata da Gianni.
the hand is been raised-FEM-SG by Gianni
‘The hand was raised by Gianni.’
b. *Ciò ha fatto alzare la mano da Gianni.
this has made raise the hand by Gianni
‘This had Gianni raise his hand.’

Thus, the FP construction shares a number of properties with the passive construction. First, the subject of the infinitive verb is optional and when it is expressed it is an adjunct as in the passive construction. Second, a number of verbs and idioms that cannot be passivized cannot appear in the FP construction as well. Third, expressions of inalienable possession can neither be passivized nor appear in the FP construction. Now that we know the properties of the FP construction, we can prove that the causative construction in which the causee is not expressed is also an instance of the FP construction.

subsection.heading: 2.3.3 Causative lacking the causee as instances of the FP construction
subsection.p: The by phrase is an adjunct and as such it can be omitted (see (26c) above). Thus, this kind of causative sentence is also an instance of the FP construction. As a matter of fact, the by phrase is optional in the FP construction, as it is in passive sentences. This claim is supported by the operativity of the same restrictions holding in causatives when the causee is expressed as da NP and also by some interpretative facts.

In section 2.3.2 above, we discussed evidence showing that a number of restrictions hold in the FP construction (and in the passive construction), but not in the FI construction. Interestingly, the same restrictions are still operative in causative sentences lacking the causee (see (30–31) above):

(32)
a. *Ciò ha fatto fare il furbo.
this has made make the smart one
‘This had (someone) be the smart one.’
b. *Ciò ha fatto alzare la mano.
this has made raise the hand
‘This had (someone) raise his hand.’

Interpretative facts discussed in Pearce (1990) also suggest that causatives lacking an overt expression of the causee are instances of the FP construction. The ambiguous expression prendere la medicina (‘take the medicine’) can either mean ingest the medicine or take hold of the medicine. When this phrase is embedded under causatives the ambiguity disappears: in FI only the first meaning is conserved, as in (33a), whereas in the FP construction only the second meaning is preserved, as in (33b):

(33)
a. La maestra ha fatto prendere la medicina al bambino.
the teacher has made take the medicine to+the child
‘The teacher made the child take the medicine.’
b. La maestra ha fatto prendere la medicina dal bambino.
the teacher has made take the medicine by+the child
‘The teacher had the child take hold of the medicine.’

Causatives lacking the causee, as in (34), retain only the second meaning, the one expressed in the FP construction in (33b). This fact can be explained only if we say that causative sentences without an overt causee are also instances of the FP construction.

(34)
La maestra ha fatto prendere la medicina.
the teacher has made take the medicine
‘The teacher had (someone) take hold of the medicine.’

In summary, in the FP construction, the causee can either be expressed by an adjunct introduced by the preposition da (‘by’) or it can be omitted. By saying that it is omitted, we want to suggest that it is not simply lexically nonovert, but that there is no empty category standing in for the causee. We have seen above that the phrase da NP cannot bind an anaphoric expression, like propri or se stesso (see (27c, d)). The same holds true in causative sentences lacking the causee. The sentences in (35) are ungrammatical since the anaphors are not bound:

(35)
a. *Faremo curare i propri interessi.
(we) will make take care of the own interests
‘We will have (someone) take care of their own interests.’
b. *La polizia fece accusare se stesso.
the police made accuse himself
‘The police had (someone) accuse himself.’

Failure to bind the anaphoric expressions in (35) suggests that the causee is syntactically absent. In fact, empty categories may serve as binders. This is illustrated in (36) where PRO binds the anaphoric expression propri in its governing category:

(36)
I ragazzi hanno promesso di PRO portare i propri libri.
the boys have promised to PRO bring the own books
‘The boys promised to take their own books.’

If the causee in (35) were structurally represented by an empty category it should be able to bind anaphoric expressions, as does PRO in (36). Since it does not, we conclude that the causee is syntactically absent in the causative construction lacking an overt expression for it. It thus seems reasonable to conclude that causative constructions lacking the causee are also instances of the FP construction.

subsection.heading: 2.3.4 Differences between the FP and the passive construction
subsection.p: Although the FP construction and the passive constructions share a number of properties, they differ in a number of respects, as pointed out in Guasti (1993). First, we observe implicit argument effects in a passive sentence. The logical subject (or external argument) of a passive sentence, the so-called implicit argument, is syntactically active: it can control PRO, as shown in (37a), and be the antecedent of anaphors, as in (37b). Notice that in (37) the by phrase cannot control PRO or bind the anaphor, since it is an adjunct. Moreover, the sentences in (37) remain well-formed even if the by phrase is absent, proving that there is indeed an implicit argument in the structure.

(37)
a. Questo edificio fu costruito (da Gaudì) per PRO ottenere un premio.
this building was built (by Gaudì) to PRO obtain a prize
b. Certi privilegi furono riservati ai propri amici (da Gianni).
some privileges were kept for own friends (by Gianni)
‘Some privileges were kept for their own friends.’

Jaeggli (1986a) and Baker (1988a) suggest that the external argument role is assigned to the passive morpheme. Being syntactically present, this argument can act as a binder in (37b) and controls PRO in (37a).

In the FP construction, binding of an anaphor and control of PRO do not obtain. As for binding, this was already discussed in 2.3.1 above. For control, this is illustrated in (38) below. The controller of PRO here can neither be the by phrase (because it is an adjunct) nor a potential implicit argument (which is not present). To the extent that the sentence is grammatical, only the matrix subject, il comandante (‘the officer’) can control PRO.

(38)
Il comandante ha fatto attaccare i nemici dal generale senza PRO avvisare il governo.
the officer has made attack the enemies by+the general without PRO informing the government
‘The officer made the enemies be attacked by the general without informing the government.’

Notice that lack of control by the logical subject of the infinitive cannot be attributed to the prominence of the matrix subject, as proven by the ungrammaticality of (39), where control by the matrix subject is inhibited and no controller for PRO is available:

(39)
*E’ la ragion di stato che ha fatto sequestrare i beni dall’ avvocato senza PRO avvisare nessuno.
(it) is the reason of state that has made confiscated the properties by+the lawyer without PRO informing nobody
‘It is reason of state that had the property be confiscated by the lawyer without informing anybody.’

The contrast between the passive sentences in (37) and the FP construction in (27) and (38) is best understood if we assume that in passive sentences the external argument which is assigned to the passive morpheme can bind and control, while the external argument is not assigned to any morpheme in the FP construction and thus cannot act as a binder or a controller. In the FP construction, the external argument can only optionally be expressed by an adjunct, the by phrase.

A second difference between the passive and the FP construction is that there are verbs that can be passivized, but cannot appear in the FP construction (see Marcantonio 1981). These are psych verbs (temere, ‘fear’), epistemic verbs (pensare, ‘think’), some verbs of perception (vedere, ‘see’; sentire, ‘hear’), verbs like perdere (‘lose’), vincere (‘win’). In (40) we have examples of passive sentences with this set of verbs. In (41) we see that these verbs cannot be embedded in the FP construction:

(40)
a. La grandine è temuta dai contadini.
the hail is feared by+the farmers
‘The hail is feared by the farmers.’
b. Un canguro è stato visto da Gianni.
a kangoroo is been seen by Gianni
‘A kangoroo was seen by Gianni.’
c. La causa è stata persa da Gianni.
the suit is been lost by Gianni
‘The suit was lost by Gianni.’

(41)
a. *La grandine ha fatto temere un disastro dai contadini.
the hail has made fear a disaster by+the farmers
‘The hail had the farmers fear a disaster.’
b. *Maria ha fatto vedere un libro da Gianni.
Maria has made see a book by Gianni
‘Maria had Gianni see a book.’
c. *L’ avvocato ha fatto perdere la causa da Gianni.
the lawyer has made loose the suit by Gianni
‘The lawyer had Gianni loose the suit.’

Thus, there are two properties that distinguish the FP construction from passives: First, there is no implicit argument in the FP construction or equivalently the logical subject is syntactically suppressed and thus is not syntactically active, as binding and control data above indicates. Second, verbs that can be passivized cannot enter the FP construction, which entails that suppression of the logical subject of the infinitive is not possible with all verbs.

subsection.heading: 2.3.5 Differences between FI and FP
subsection.p: We observed in the section above that there are a number of restrictions holding in the FP construction. It is interesting to observe that all the restrictions holding in the FP construction do not hold in the FI construction. First, some verbal expressions that cannot be passivized cannot be found in the FP construction (section 2.3.2). However, these verbal expressions yield perfectly grammatical results in the FI construction, as observed in Burzio (1986). In fact, if the causee is expressed by a PP headed by the preposition a, rather than by the by phrase, the sentences in (30b) and (31b) become grammatical. Compare (30b) and (31b) with (42a) and (42b), respectively:

(42)
a. Ciò ha fatto fare il furbo a Gianni.
this has made make the smart one to Gianni
‘This made Gianni be the smart one.’
b. Ciò ha fatto alzare la mano a Gianni.
this has made raise the hand to Gianni
‘This made Gianni raise his hand.’
(42) shows that there is no intrinsic incompatibility between idiomatic expressions, expressions of inalienable possession, and causatives.

Second, we observed that some verbs cannot be found in the FP construction (section 2.3.4). Interestingly, all those verbs can be embedded in the FI construction. In contrast to the ungrammatical sentences in (41) we have the grammatical sentences in (43):

(43)
a. La grandine ha fatto temere un disastro ai contadini.
the hail has made fear a disaster to+the farmers
‘The hail made the farmers fear a disaster.’
b. Maria ha fatto vedere un libro a Gianni.
Maria has made see a book to Gianni
‘Maria made Gianni see a book.’
c. L’ avvocato ha fatto perdere la causa a Gianni.
the lawyer has made lose the suit to Gianni
‘The lawyer made Gianni lose the suit.’
Third, Hyman and Zimmer (1976) observe that the FP and the FI constructions have different interpretations. Consider the two sentences in (44):

(44)
a. I soldati fecero pulire le toilette al generale.
the soldiers made clean the toilets to+the general
‘The soldiers made the general clean the toilets.’
b. I soldati fecero pulire le toilette dal generale.
the soldiers made clean the toilets by+the general
‘The soldiers made the general clean the toilets.’

When the causee is expressed by an a NP, as in (44a), the interpretation is that the soldiers want the toilets to be cleaned and they want the general to do it and not someone else. The soldiers cause an event to take place and this causation is directed toward the general or the general is affected by the event caused. By contrast, when the causee is expressed by an adjunct da NP, the interpretation is that the soldiers caused an event, that of the toilets being cleaned. The general happened to do it, but this is incidental (see also Lepschy 1978).

subsection.heading: 2.3.6 Summary
subsection.p: The major differences between the two causative constructions, FI and FP, found in Romance are the following. First, the logical subject of the infinitive is syntactically suppressed in the FP construction and is optionally expressed as an adjunct (the by phrase). By contrast, it is projected in an argumental position in the FI construction. Second, suppression of the logical subject of the infinitive in the FP construction is subject to restrictions: some verbs cannot be found in the FP construction, but they can appear in the FI construction. Third, certain verbal expressions (of inalienable possession, verbs of measure) cannot be embedded in the FP construction, but can be found in the FI construction. Fourth, the meaning of the two kinds of sentences is not the same. In the FI construction an event is caused and this causation is directed toward the causee; in the FP construction, just the event is caused.

subsection.heading: 2.4 Theoretical accounts of causatives
subsection.p: We have seen that Romance causatives are special in that the causative verb and the verb embedded under it behave as a single verb as far as syntax is concerned. Moreover, we have also seen that there are two causative constructions: FI and FP that differs in several respects. Having surveyed the major properties of causative constructions, we can now move on and examine how these can be handled.

subsection.heading: 2.4.1 Causative complements as bare lexical structures
subsection.p: Clauses are the projections of a verb augmented with a number of functional projections (Pollock 1989; Cinque 1999, among others). Within such a framework, differences between infinitival complements after causative verbs and other ordinary infinitival complements with respect to various syntactic processes, like cliticization, can be understood by assuming that these complements do not include the full array of functional categories found in other finite and infinitival clauses. The table in (45) below summarizes the functional projections of the clausal domain and the overt evidence for these projections:

(45)
Projection
CP
AgrSP
NegP
TP
AgrOP
Evidence Wh-movement Agreement SVO Negation Aspectual auxiliary Accusative case

First, there is no wh-movement inside causative complements, suggesting that CP is not present. Second, AgrSP is usually associated with the presence of overt agreement and of overt preverbal subjects. As we have seen, a preverbal subject is disallowed in Romance causative complements, suggesting that a position for it is not available. Further support for this claim comes from European Portuguese. As we saw in sections 1 and 2, there are two (or three) kinds of causative complements in this language, one similar to that found in the other Romance languages (see (3) above) and displaying the order VOS and one similar to that found in English and displaying the order SVO (see (7) above). As we said earlier, when the order is SV(O), there are two possibilities: the infinitive in the causative complement can either be inflected, in which case subject agreement is attested, or not. When the order is VOS, an inflected infinitive is not possible. One natural way to interpret this contrast is that the causative complements displaying the order VOS, the one that is typically found in all Romance languages, does not include AgrSP, while the other complement displaying the order SV(O) includes AgrSP. Interestingly, when AgrSP is overtly present, the causee receives nominative case, as proven by the fact that it can be expressed by a nominative pronoun: O professor mandou eles sairem (‘The professor made they leave-Agr’) (from Gonçalves 1999). When AgrSP is not overtly present, the causee gets accusative case as in E(xceptional) C(ase) M(arking) structures. Let us continue with the examination of the other projections. Third, negation non (‘not’) cannot be present in causative complements. Since non is assumed to be the head of NegP (see Zanuttini 1996), its absence from causative complements suggests that NegP is unavailable in such complements:

(46)
*Gianni ha fatto non bere più Paolo.
Gianni has made not drink anymore Paolo
‘Gianni made Paolo not drink anymore.’
Similarly, (aspectual) auxiliaries cannot be present in causative complements, as shown in (47).

(47)
Marco farà aver letto i libro a Gianni per domani.
Marco will make have read the book to Gianni by tomorrow
‘Marco will make Gianni have read the book by tomorrow.’

This restriction can be explained as follows. Because of their interpretive properties, aspectual auxiliaries are either located in tense or need to be licensed by tense. The unavailability of aspectual auxiliaries may be taken as evidence that TP is absent from causative complements. Finally, AgrOP is the position where structural accusative case is checked. As shown by the distribution of clitics, (see, e.g., (9)), structural case cannot be checked inside causative complements, a fact that may be interpreted as evidence that AgrOP is not present in such complements.

The data examined so far are best interpreted by assuming that causative complements do not include any functional projection, in contrast to other infinitival complements (that do not display the restriction examined in the previous sections). Under the assumption that the thematic information associated with a verb is expressed within a vP (Larson 1988b; Hale and Keyser 1993b; Chomsky 2000), it is plausible to assume that causative complements are bare lexical structures that at most project up to vPs. The lower VP includes the verbal head and the complement; the higher vP includes a v-head to which the infinitive verb moves and the position for the external argument. In the following sections, we will refine this conjecture in view of the different properties of the two causative constructions, FI and FP.

subsection.heading: 2.4.2 The structure of infinitival complements in the FI construction
subsection.p: We have established that the causee is an argument in the FI construction, precisely it is the thematic subject of the infinitive. It has been proposed that the position of the subject is submitted to parametric variation, that is, it can be located either to the left or to the right of the verbal head. For Romance, the subject position seems to be to the right (cf. Bonet 1990; Giorgi and Longobardi 1991; Koopman and Sportiche 1991b; Friedemann 1997). Based on this hypothesis, the proposal is that in causative complements the subject surfaces in the base-generated position to the right of the verbal head. For concreteness, we assume that the subject position is Spec vP, and that this Spec position is to the right. Causative complements in the FI construction have the structure in (48):

The subject or the external argument of a transitive or an intransitive verb stays in its base position that in Romance is located to the right of the vP head. The internal argument of a transitive verb occupies the V sister position of the lower VP. This hypothesis grants in the same structural status to the external argument of a transitive or an intransitive ergative verb: in both cases they remain the external argument of the selected verb. As for why the case properties of these two arguments vary, the reader can refer to 2.4.5.2.

subsection.heading: 2.4.3 The structure of infinitival complements in the FP construction
subsection.p: In the FP construction, the logical subject of the infinitive or the external argument is syntactically suppressed, as an argument (see section 2.3.4). When it is expressed, it surfaces in an adjunct phrase, the by phrase. These facts can be best accounted for by assuming that the complement of the causative verb in the FP construction is a bare VP lacking the higher vP and thus a position for the external argument (an idea that was already in Burzio 1986), as in (49). The internal argument occupies the V sister position and the adjunct causee is adjoined to the VP, when present.

(49)
[VP fare [VP [V riparare] [DP la macchina]]]
[VP make [VP [V repair] [DP the car]]]

Unaccusative verbs also lack the thematic subject and only have internal arguments, as complements of causative in the FP construction. The natural assumption is that in causatives based on unaccusative verb, the complement is a VP lacking the vP and thus the position for the external argument; therefore, the structure of causative complements based on transitive verbs in the FP construction and on unaccusative verbs is the same, a VP without the projection of the external argument (as in Burzio 1986). This captures the fact that in both cases the complement selected by the causative verb does not include an external argument.

In the 1980s it was generally assumed that causative complements were like full clauses, that is, they projected at least up to IP (or AgrSP in the Pollockian framework) (Burzio 1986; Zubizarreta 1986) or even to CP (Baker 1988a). Essentially, this assumption was forced by the fact that subjects were assumed to be generated in SpecIP (or SpecAgrSP). Therefore, IP was necessary to accommodate the subject of causative complements. The hypothesis that subjects are generated in a vP (a lexical structure that includes all thematic information associated to the verb) made the abandonment of such an analysis possible in favor of one that more accurately takes account of restrictions and distributional properties of expressions in causative complements.

In summary, the causative verb can either select a vP including a position for the external argument or a VP from which the higher vP is missing and thus a position for the external argument is lacking. In this case, the logical subject or the external argument is suppressed and is optionally expressed by an adjunct. We return later to the different selectional properties of the causative verbs.

subsection.heading: 2.4.4 Romance causatives and the process of complex predicate formation
subsection.p: The causative complement is a vP headed by the infinitive verb. In section 2.2 we have shown that the causative verb and the infinitive behave as a syntactic unit with respect to a number of processes, such as cliticization and NP-movement under passives. Various notions have been advocated in the literature to express this fact: reanalysis (Rouveret and Vergnaud 1980; Manzini 1983b), verb raising (Aissen 1974), merger (Marantz 1984; Rosen 1989), clause union (Gibson 1980). The common idea behind these various notions is that of transforming a biclausal structure or a structure with two distinct clauses (one for the causative and one for the infinitive verb) into one single clause. For example, reanalysis is the process by which two independent verbs are reanalyzed as a single verb. Reanalysis can be expressed through indexation, as in (50):

(50)
Maria fai
ripararei
la macchina a Gianni.
Maria makes repair the car to Gianni
‘Maria makes Gianni repair the car.’

Although these notions capture the relevant data, they remain ad hoc devices with a limited explanatory power. Detailed work on morphological causatives (Baker 1988a) has prompted an analysis of causatives through the notion of incorporation, itself an instantiation of movement of one head to another head. Unlike other notions mentioned above, head movement is not construction specific and its application is quite widespread. One familiar case is movement of the verbal head to inflectional heads. In causatives, it is the infinitive that moves to the higher verbal head, the causative verb, and forms with it a complex verb fare + riparare.

subsection.heading: 2.4.5 Head-movement in Romance causatives
subsection.p: At D-structure, the infinitive and the causative verbs head two verbal projections. By S-structure, the infinitive moves to v (if present) and then higher up to incorporate into the causative verb, thus forming a complex verb with it, as in (51):

(51)
[VP fare ripararei [vP [v′ [v ti] [VP [V ti] [DP la macchina]]] a Gianni]]
[VP make repairi [vP [v′ [v ti] [VP [V ti] [DP the car]]] to Gianni]]

The claim that in causative sentences the infinitive does not stay in its base position, but moves higher up, is supported by word-order facts. Consider the example in (52) (see Guasti 1993; Den Dikken 1995c):

(52)
I professorij
facevano commentare tuttij
il libro a Ugo.
the professors made comment all the book to Ugo
‘The professors all made Ugo comment on the book.’

Sportiche (1988) proposed that Floating Quantifiers (FQs) occur in positions which the subject has moved through on its way from its base position (inside vP) to the specifier of the higher projection, AgrSP. In (52), the matrix subject, i professori (‘the professors’), has stranded the FQ tutti (‘all’) in a position close to the matrix vP. From the order in (52), causative-infinitive-FQ, we must conclude that the infinitive has moved from the causative complement to a position inside the matrix sentence, as displayed in (53). Thus, the infinitive must move and form a complex head with the causative verb overtly.
(53) [IP I professorij [facevano commentarei]k [vP tuttij tk [VP ti quel libro a Ugo]]]
Thus, there is no special rule of causative formation: causative sentences are derived by a primitive process operating in various constructions, head-movement.

subsection.heading: 2.4.5.1 Potential problems and further refinements
subsection.p: One potential problem for this approach is that the causative and the infinitive verb can be separated by adverbial elements as shown in (54).

(54)
I professorij
fanno spesso commentare tuttij
il libro a Ugo.
the professors make often comment all the book to Ugo
‘The professors all make Ugo often comment on the book.’
Moreover, in French interrogative sentences, it is only the causative verb that precedes the clitic subject, as (55) shows (see Kayne 1975):

(55)
Fera-t-il reparer la voiture a Jean?
make-he repair the car to Jean?
‘Does he make Jean repair the car?’

If the causative and the infinitive formed a single complex head, they should not be separable, contrary to facts. Thus, on the one hand, there is evidence that head-to-head movement occurs in Romance causatives to form a complex verbal head. On the other, the causative verb and the infinitive may be separated. To accommodate all these facts, one can appeal to the notion of excorporation, another instance of head-movement. Romance causatives allow excorporation of the causative head from the complex verb previously formed by incorporation. The causative verb excorporates and moves alone to T and AgrS. In other words, Romance causatives are the result of two processes: incorporation and excorporation (for the technical execution of this proposal, see Roberts 1991a; Guasti 1993).

subsection.heading: 2.4.5.2 Consequences of incorporation
subsection.p: Causative constructions are an instance of verb incorporation, or head-to-head movement. This is the primitive property responsible for all the other properties manifested by Romance causatives and illustrated in section 2.2. As shown by Baker (1988a), verb incorporation disrupts the usual government relationships and creates new government relationships. It also alters the usual grammatical functions. The incorporation host (the causative verb) and the incorporee (the infinitive verb) become a single complex verb that inherits properties from its components and governs every argument governed by its constituent parts, as established by the Government Transparency Corollary (GTC), which states that:

GTC: A lexical category, which has an item incorporated into it governs everything which the incorporated item governed in its original structural position.
(Baker 1988a: 64)

As a consequence of the formation of a complex verb, a single thematic grid is formed that includes arguments from each single verb. Therefore, the arguments of the infinitive become arguments of the complex verb. Under the assumption that case is assigned under government, the GTC also accounts for the case pattern found in causatives. In a language a complex verb cannot have more case assignment possibilities than a simplex verb. A simple verb in Romance assigns a single structural accusative case as shown in (56):

(56)
Ho dato un libro a Maria.
(I) have given a book to Maria

Here the direct object is assigned accusative case, while the indirect object is marked with the dative case expressed by the preposition a (‘to’) in front of the noun. A complex verb behaves in the same way as far as case assignment is concerned. Formation of a complex verb and case assignment abilities of this verb account for the process of grammatical function change that we observe in causatives. The external argument of the infinitive becomes the direct or indirect object of the complex verb depending on the transitivity of the verb and the direct object of the infinitive becomes the direct object of the complex verb. This change of grammatical functions is overtly shown by the processes of cliticization and NP-movement under passive that we discussed in section 2.2. We will illustrate this by means of the example in (6), repeated here:

(6)
Paolo ha fatto ridere la classe.
Paolo has made laugh the class
‘Paolo made the class laugh.’

In (6), la classe (‘the class’) is the logical subject of the infinitive. However, due to the incorporation process it is now governed by, and becomes the direct object of, the newly created complex verb fa-ridere. The complex verb assigns accusative case to the DP la classe (‘the class’). When realized as a clitic, it cliticizes in front of the complex verb, as in (18), repeated below:

(18)
Paolo l’ ha fatta ridere.
Paolo her has made-FEM laugh
‘Paolo made her laugh.’

When the causative verb is passivized, the complex verb of which it is part is unable to assign accusative case and la classe, originally an argument of the infinitive, becomes the subject of the passivized complex verb fatto-ridere.

subsection.heading: 2.4.5.3 Summary
subsection.p: In summary, the primitive property that is responsible for the behavior of Romance causatives is incorporation, or the process of head-to-head movement that creates a complex verb formed by the causative and the infinitive verb. As a side-effect of incorporation, the grammatical functions, the government relationships, and the properties of case assignment of the causative and of the infinitive verb are altered. This explains the exceptional behavior of the arguments of the infinitives, as far as case, cliticization, and passivization are concerned. Incorporation occurs in the syntax and is accompanied by a process of excorporation, ‘another instance of head movement’ that takes place to allow the causative verb to check its tense and agreement feature.

subsection.heading: 2.4.6 Selectional properties of the causative verb
subsection.p: It was proposed above that the causative verb can take a vP complement including the external argument of the infinitive or a VP lacking a position for this. Moreover, we saw that the two causative constructions FI and FP have different meanings. We can capture these observations by assuming that the causative verb can be associated to either of the thematic grids in (57):

(57)
Fare
thematic grid
<<causer/agent, event> benefactive> FI
<causer/agent, event> FP

The causative verb selects a causer and an event in the FP construction. The event is syntactically realized as a VP lacking the position for an external argument or subject. This hypothesis captures the idea that in this case, the causer wants some event to happen or some action to be carried out. In the FI construction, instead, the causation of the event is direct or is to the benefit of someone, hence the additional selection of a benefactive role (if positively affected, or a ‘victim’ if negatively affected). This role is assigned under government to the causee in the FI construction, which in this way receives two thematic roles, one from the causative verb and one from the infinitive. This proposal is compatible with versions of the Theta Criterion in (58) (Chomsky 1986b) according to which a single DP is allowed to receive more than one theta-role provided these are assigned to the same position:
(58) Theta Criterion: Each argument α appears in a chain containing a unique visible theta position P, and each theta position P is visible in a chain containing a unique argument α.
(Chomsky 1986b: 97)
Alternatively, one may also say that the two roles are fused together after the formation of a complex predicate and the ensuing creation of a single thematic grid (see also Alsina 1992).

subsection.heading: 2.4.7 An account of some differences between the FI and the FP constructions
subsection.p: Verb incorporation accounts for the major similarities between the FI and the FP constructions with respect to cliticization and NP-movement. However, the two constructions display a number of different properties. One is that the causee is an argument in the former case, while it is an adjunct in the latter (see section 2.3.1). The assumptions adopted in the 2.4.2 and 2.4.3 account for the different status of the causee in the two constructions as follows. Since the causee is projected into an argument position in the former case, it can act as a binder and can control PRO. By contrast, control and binding by the causee or by an implicit argument do not obtain in the FP construction because there is no implicit argument (sections 2.3.3, 2.3.4) and because when expressed the causee is an adjunct. Under the plausible assumption that expressions of inalienable possession are anaphoric to the possessor (see Kayne 1975), the ill-formedness of (32b) can be explained by appealing to the lack of an appropriate binder. As for idiomatic expressions like fare il furbo (‘be the smart one’) that cannot occur in the FP construction (as shown in (30b)), Burzio (1986) proposes that some sort of anaphoric relation exists between the subject and the idiomatic object, an idea that is suggested by the fact that the subject and the object agree, as exemplified by Maria fa la furba (lit. Maria-FEM makes the smart-FEM) where Maria and la furba are both in the feminine gender. If this view is correct, the ungrammaticality of (34b) is again a case of binding failure. 1

We observed in section 2.3.2 that the FP construction resembles the passive construction. This similarity can be understood as follows. As observed by Burzio (1986), under the Principles and Parameters model there is no construction specific rule, that is, there is no rule of passivization. Instead, there are various operations and phenomena that can cluster or can occur in isolation. Passive sentences are characterized by (i) the introduction of the passive morphology; (ii) the movement of the object into subject position; (iii) the presence of an implicit argument or, optionally, of a by phrase. These three phenomena cluster in passive sentences because the introduction of the passive morphology absorbs accusative case. Thus, the object is forced to move to the subject position to receive case. The passive morpheme receives the role of the external argument and transmits this role to a doubling by phrase (Baker 1988a). In the FP construction, there is no passive morphology, no absorption of accusative case, and no movement of the object. The logical subject of the infinitive is suppressed in the lexicon. Optionally, it can be expressed with a by phrase that is licensed by the argument structure associated with the infinitive, precisely by the position that is lexically suppressed, as in Grimshaw (1990). One question that still needs an answer is what regulates the suppression of the external argument of the infinitive in the FP construction, an issue that we examine in the next section.

subsection.heading: 2.4.8 The FP construction and the affectedness constraint
subsection.p: In section 2.3.5 we saw that certain verbs cannot enter in the FP construction. These are psych verbs (temere, ‘fear’), epistemic verbs (pensare, ‘think’), some verbs of perception (vedere, ‘see’; sentire, ‘hear’), verbs like perdere (‘lose’), vincere (‘win’). According to Guasti (1993, 1996a), this restriction can be expressed by the Affectedness Constraint. She notes that the restrictions operating in FP also operate in passive nominals (see Anderson 1977a; Jaeggli 1986a; Roberts 1987). The object of a noun, such as city in (59a) undergoes NP-movement in passive nominals, as in (59b):

(59)
a. Attila's destruction of the city
b. The city's destruction (by Attila)
Passivization is forbidden with certain types of nouns, as the following contrasts witness:

(60)
a. John's loss of the job
b. *The job's loss (by John)
c. Mary's fear of storms
d. *Storms’ fear (by Mary)

Jaeggli (1986a) proposes that in passive nominals the external argument is not syntactically projected because it is suppressed in the lexicon. Therefore, the prenominal position remains empty and is available for the object to move there, as in (59b). However, suppression of the external argument is possible only when the object of the noun is affected by the process described by the noun. In (59a), the object of the noun destruction is affected and thus the external argument of this noun can be suppressed. Then, NP-movement of the object to the pronominal position is possible. By contrast, the external argument of loss or fear cannot be suppressed. The prenominal position must be filled with it and thus movement of the object of these nouns to the preverbal position cannot occur. Extending this line of thinking, Guasti (1993, 1996a) claims that suppression of the external argument of the infinitive embedded under a causative verb can only occur when the object of the infinitive is affected by the process described by the infinitive, as happens with verbs like riparare (‘repair’). By contrast, with psych verbs, epistemic verbs, some verbs of perception, lose and win, the object is unaffected and the external argument cannot be suppressed but must be syntactically projected. Thus, the FP construction cannot be formed with such verbs. One might wonder why the Affectedness Constraint applies in Romance causatives as it does in passive nominals. In (verbal) passives, we observe a change of grammatical functions (GF) and the presence of overt morphology, the passive morpheme signaling this change. Usually a GF changing process is sanctioned by morphology. However, there are cases where this does not happen. Passive nominals are a case in point. The noun does not have different morphology in (60a), an active nominal and in (60b), a passive nominal. A second case is causative constructions. In the FI and in the FP constructions we observe a GF changing process not sanctioned by a morphological marker. It is possible that when GF changing processes are not morphologically marked, their power should be somewhat restricted or equivalently it can be limited to a set of verbs with special characteristics (see Pesetsky 1990 on this issue). Under this view the Affectedness Constraint that operates in the FP construction may be viewed as a condition limiting the power of grammatical changing processes and thus ensuring recoverability of the lexically suppressed argument.

subsection.heading: 2.4.9 Summary
subsection.p: Romance has two causative structures, both derived by syntactic incorporation. These structures are semantically different and this is expressed by assuming that the causative verb is associated to two thematic grids, one including a causer/agent and an event, the other also including a benefactive role. The event is structurally realized as a VP in the FP construction or a vP in the FI construction. While the external argument is present in the latter case, it is not in the former (since there is no position for it). Lack of the external argument and thus formation of the FP construction is possible only if the internal argument of the infinitive is affected by the process described by the infinitive itself.

subsection.heading: 3 Conclusion
subsection.p: Romance causatives include two verbs that syntactically behave as a single verb that takes as arguments the arguments of the two single verbs. This behavior has been explained by appealing to the notion of verb incorporation of head-to-head movement. The syntactic properties manifested by the arguments of the infinitive after a causative verb follow from this process. Romance has two causative constructions that convey different meanings and display different lexico-semantic restrictions. These differences have been captured first by assuming that the causative verb is associated to two thematic grids and second by appealing to the Affectedness Constraint.

There is variation among causative constructions that are not accounted for by the proposals discussed in the previous section. One is the failure to form passive causative sentences in French and for some speakers in Spanish too; another is that in French/Spanish reflexive verbs, like se laver/lavarse (‘to wash -self’) can be embedded under the causative verb, while their Italian counterpart, lavarsi, cannot, as the contrast in (61) shows:

(61)
a. Juan hizo lavarse las manos a Maria.
b. Jean faisait se laver les mains à Marie.
c. *Gianni faceva lavarsi le mani a Maria.
John made wash-self the hands to Maria
‘John made Mary wash her hands.’
In Italian, the reflexive clitic must be omitted as displayed in (62), although the sentence maintains the same meaning as the Spanish and French sentences in (61a) and (61b):

(62)
Gianni ha fatto lavare le mani a Maria.
John has made wash-self the hands to Maria
‘John made Mary wash her hands.’
Interestingly, in EP the reflexive clitic cannot be present in a construction comparable to the one in (62) with the causee at the end of the clause, as the contrast between (63a) and (63b) shows. 2

(63)
a. *O João mandou barbear-se o Pedro.
the João made shave-self the Pedro
‘João made shave himself Pedro.’
b. O João mandou barbear o Pedro.
the João made shave the Pedro
‘João made shave Pedro.’
The reflexive clitic can be present in EP causatives when the order of the arguments of the complement is SV(O), as in (64):

(64)
O João mandou o Pedro barbear-se.
the João made the Pedro shave-self
‘João made shave himself Pedro.’

These facts support the idea advanced in section 2.4.1 that causative complements displaying the order SV(O) are not bare vP, but include functional projection (e.g., AgrSP). Under the assumption that reflexive clitics are located in AgrSP or in some other functional projection, the contrast between (63a) and (64) can be explained by saying that AgrSP is present in the latter case, but not in the former, that is, causative complements displaying the order VOS are bare lexical structures, while causative complements displaying the order SV(O) include functional projections (see Guasti 1993, 1996a for a development of these ideas; see Zubizarreta 1986 for an alternative proposal about the distribution of reflexive clitics in causatives).

By contrast, the Italian sentence in (62) has a reflexive interpretation (Guasti 1993). This fact may depend on the availability in EP, but not in Italian, of the ECM construction in (64) to express the reflexive interpretation.
